Award.AwardTitle: NeTS: Small: Resource-Aware Crowdsourcing in Wireless Networks

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Division.LongName: Division Of Computer and Network Systems

Award.AbstractNarration:
Transmitting large numbers of photos in a wireless environment with bandwidth constraints is challenging. In this project, the research team aims to develop a framework to quantify the quality of crowdsourced photos based on the accessible geographical and geometrical information (called metadata) including the smartphone's orientation, position and all related parameters of the built-in camera. From the metadata, information such as where and how the photo is taken can be inferred, and then only the most useful photos may be transmitted. Specifically, the project addresses three closely intertwined issues in resource-aware crowdsourcing. The first part investigates how to select photos based on the collected metadata by considering two scenarios: Point of Interest where the selected photos should be about a specific location or object, and Area of Interest where selected photos are related to an area. For both cases, various algorithms are designed to quantify the coverage of the photos based on the metadata, and then to select the minimum number of photos based on the coverage requirement, or to select a predefined number of photos to maximize the photo coverage. The second part focuses on metadata transmission and redundancy removal when crowdsourcing is based on peer-to-peer (P2P) communications. The third part investigates techniques to automatically and accurately generate metadata based on sensors available on most off-the-shelf smartphones.

The proposed research could potentially have substantial impacts on emergency responders and service providers by allowing them to identify the most useful information from crowdsourced photos under resource constraints. The results from this research are likely to foster new research directions on supporting resource-aware crowdsourcing in wireless networks. The project will engage under-represented students in the proposed research. The scholarly discovery of this project will be disseminated broadly to the community.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Equipped with mega-pixel cameras and various motion sensors, smartphones have become effective tools for crowdsourcing of image data that can be used in many emerging applications including disaster recovery and map services with virtual tours. However, the crowdsourced images have large amount of redundancy and transmitting all of them to the server will waste lots of communication bandwidth, storage capacity and computation power.  The techniques for photo collection and analysis envisioned so far are not well designed for scenarios where resources are limited.  The mismatch between the scarce resource and the sheer number of crowdsourced photos demands that only the most useful photos are selected and transmitted. To address these issues, we propose a framework to quantify the quality of crowdsourced photos based on the accessible geographical and geometrical information (called metadata) including the smartphone’s orientation, position and all related parameters of the built-in camera. From the metadata, we can infer where and how the photo is taken, and then only transmit the most useful photos with limited resources.

Through this project, various techniques have been developed to address three closely intertwined issues in resource-aware crowdsourcing.  First, we have developed techniques to automatically generate metadata when photos are taken.  By making use of multiple embedded sensors in off-the-shelf smartphones, we have developed a series of methods to fuse data, correct errors, and filter out false information, to improve the accuracy of the collected metadata.  Second, we have designed and evaluated techniques to collect metadata and photos.  With cellular networks, data can be easily transmitted. However, in many scenarios such as disaster recovery, cellular network may be partly damaged or not available. Then, the metadata or the real photos may have to be transmitted based on Peer-to-Peer (P2P) networks via other communication links such as WiFi/Bluetooth. Thus, we have designed and evaluated efficient schemes for metadata/photo transmission and redundancy removal using wireless P2P networks.  Third, we have designed and evaluated techniques to select photos based on the collected metadata.  We consider two scenarios: Point of Interest where the selected photos should be about a specific location or object, and Area of Interest where selected photos are related to an area.  For both cases, we develop techniques to quantify the usefulness (coverage) of the photos based on the metadata, and then select the minimum number of photos based on the coverage requirement or select a predefined number of photos to maximize the photo coverage.  Four optimization problems regarding the tradeoffs between photo utility and resource constraints have been studied. Efficient algorithms have been proposed and their performance bounds have been theoretically proved.  Extensive evaluations based on real implementations and simulations have demonstrated the effectiveness of the proposed techniques.

Many of the research results have been integrated with the education curricula at the Pennsylvania State University. The project has supported three Ph.D.  students working on their dissertations and two undergraduate students have participated in the research. The involvement of the graduate and undergraduate students will prepare them for leadership roles in computer science research, academia, and industry.
